expanded_description: Matrices are rectangular arrays of numbers that organize and process information in ways that ordinary algebra cannot. They are the backbone of computer graphics, data science, economics, physics, and engineering. Before matrices can do anything powerful — solving systems of equations, encoding messages, rotating shapes — you need to be comfortable with the basic operations: adding, subtracting, and scaling them. This section builds that foundation from the ground up.

core_concept.principle: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers arranged in rows and columns. Matrix operations — addition, subtraction, and scalar multiplication — work element by element, operating on corresponding entries. Two matrices can only be added or subtracted if they have exactly the same dimensions.
core_concept.explanation: Think of a matrix as a spreadsheet: rows going across, columns going down, and each cell holding a number. When you add two spreadsheets together, you add the number in each cell of the first spreadsheet to the number in the same cell of the second spreadsheet. That's exactly how matrix addition works — position by position, entry by entry. This is called element-wise or entry-wise operation, and it is the defining logic of all three operations in this section. Scalar multiplication is even simpler: multiply every single entry in the matrix by the same number (the scalar). These operations are the vocabulary you need before matrix multiplication, inverses, and all the powerful applications ahead.

sections.section_title: What Is a Matrix? — Vocabulary and Notation
sections.introduction: Before we can do any operations, we need precise language for talking about matrices. This vocabulary appears on every assessment in this unit — know it cold. Many students skip this section thinking it's 'just definitions,' then lose points on notation errors for the rest of the unit.

key_concept.definition: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers enclosed in brackets. The numbers inside are called entries or elements. A matrix is described by its dimensions: $m \times n$ (read '$m$ by $n$'), where $m$ is the number of rows and $n$ is the number of columns. A matrix named $A$ with entry in row $i$ and column $j$ is written $a_{ij}$ (lowercase letter with subscript).
key_concept.context: Rows run horizontally (left to right). Columns run vertically (up to down). When stating dimensions, ALWAYS say rows first, then columns — $m \times n$ means $m$ rows and $n$ columns. This order is universal in mathematics and must be memorized. A matrix is usually named with a capital letter ($A$, $B$, $C$) and individual entries with the corresponding lowercase letter and subscripts ($a_{11}$, $a_{12}$, etc.). The subscript $a_{ij}$ is read 'a sub i j' — $i$ is the row number, $j$ is the column number.

classifications.value: Always identify dimension before performing any operation — it determines what is and isn't allowed
characteristics: Dimension = (number of rows) $\times$ (number of columns), written $m \times n$
Rows are horizontal — count them going down
Columns are vertical — count them going across
A $2 \times 3$ matrix has 2 rows and 3 columns (6 total entries)
A $3 \times 2$ matrix has 3 rows and 2 columns (also 6 entries — but different shape)
A $2 \times 3$ and a $3 \times 2$ are NOT the same — dimension order matters
A square matrix has equal rows and columns: $n \times n$
A $1 \times n$ matrix (one row) is called a row vector; an $m \times 1$ matrix (one column) is a column vector
classifications.behavior: To find dimensions: count the horizontal strips (rows) — that's $m$. Count the vertical strips (columns) — that's $n$. Write $m \times n$. Do this before any calculation. The most common dimension error is reversing rows and columns. A reliable check: does the matrix look wider (more columns than rows) or taller (more rows than columns)? A $2 \times 4$ matrix is wide; a $4 \times 2$ is tall.

examples.explanation: $A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 7 & -1 \\ 0 & 4 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$. Count horizontal strips: 2 rows. Count vertical strips: 3 columns. Dimension: $2 \times 3$. The matrix looks wide — more columns than rows. There are $2 \times 3 = 6$ total entries.

$B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -2 \\ 3 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$. 2 rows, 2 columns. Dimension: $2 \times 2$. This is a square matrix — equal rows and columns. Square matrices are special: only square matrices can have determinants and inverses (Sections 14.3–14.5).

$C = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ -1 \\ 7 \end{bmatrix}$. 3 rows, 1 column. Dimension: $3 \times 1$. This is a column vector. It looks like a tall, single-column matrix. Column vectors are the output of matrix-vector multiplication in Section 14.4.

classifications.value: Read and write entry notation fluently — it appears in every matrix formula in this unit
characteristics: $a_{ij}$ is the entry in row $i$, column $j$ of matrix $A$
The row index $i$ is always listed first — then the column index $j$
$a_{11}$ is always the top-left entry (row 1, column 1)
$a_{12}$ is row 1, column 2 — one step right from $a_{11}$
$a_{21}$ is row 2, column 1 — one step down from $a_{11}$
Think of it like a map coordinate: row is your latitude (up/down), column is your longitude (left/right)
classifications.behavior: When asked for $a_{ij}$, move to row $i$ first (count down from the top), then column $j$ (count right from the left). The subscript reads like an address: $a_{23}$ means 'row 2, column 3 — go to the second row, then find the third entry in it.' Practicing reading $a_{ij}$ notation fluently now pays off in Section 14.2 (matrix multiplication) where correct entry identification is critical.

examples.explanation: $A = \begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 & 8 \\ 1 & 0 & -4 \\ 3 & 7 & 6 \end{bmatrix}$. Find $a_{11}$: row 1, column 1 → $5$. Find $a_{23}$: row 2, column 3 → $-4$. Find $a_{32}$: row 3, column 2 → $7$. Find $a_{13}$: row 1, column 3 → $8$. Note: $a_{23} \neq a_{32}$ — the order of subscripts matters.

$B = \begin{bmatrix} 10 & 3 \\ -5 & 7 \end{bmatrix}$. What is $a_{12}$? Row 1, column 2 → $3$. What entry is at row 2, column 1? That's $a_{21} = -5$. If asked 'what is the entry in row 2, column 2?', write $a_{22} = 7$.

classifications.value: Recognize these on sight — they appear throughout Unit 14
characteristics: Square matrix: $n \times n$ — same number of rows and columns; can have determinants and inverses
Row matrix (row vector): $1 \times n$ — a single row
Column matrix (column vector): $m \times 1$ — a single column
Zero matrix $O$: every entry is 0; the additive identity for matrices (like 0 for numbers)
Equal matrices: two matrices are equal if and only if they have the same dimensions AND every corresponding entry is equal
A $2 \times 3$ matrix and a $3 \times 2$ matrix are NEVER equal — dimensions must match first
classifications.behavior: When two matrices are set equal to each other, every corresponding entry must be equal. This creates a system of equations — one equation for each entry. Setting matrices equal is a technique used in Section 14.3 (finding unknowns by matching entries). Equal matrices must have identical dimensions as a prerequisite; if the dimensions differ, equality is impossible regardless of entries.

examples.explanation: Are $\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 5 \\ -1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}$ and $\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 5 \\ -1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}$ equal? Same dimensions ($2 \times 2$) ✓. All corresponding entries match: $2=2$, $5=5$, $-1=-1$, $3=3$ ✓. Yes — they are equal.

examples.process: Using Equality to Solve for Unknowns
examples.explanation: $\begin{bmatrix} x+1 & 4 \\ 3 & y-2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 7 & 4 \\ 3 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$. Entry $(1,1)$: $x + 1 = 7 \Rightarrow x = 6$. Entry $(2,2)$: $y - 2 = 5 \Rightarrow y = 7$. Solving via entry-by-entry equality creates a simple system of equations.

sections.introduction: Matrix addition is the most intuitive matrix operation — if you can add numbers, you can add matrices. The key rule is simple but absolute: you can only add two matrices if they have exactly the same dimensions. Then you add entry by entry, position by position.

key_concept.definition: To add two matrices $A$ and $B$ of the same dimension, add their corresponding entries: the entry in row $i$, column $j$ of $A + B$ is $a_{ij} + b_{ij}$. The result is a new matrix with the same dimension as $A$ and $B$.
key_concept.context: Matrix addition is commutative ($A + B = B + A$) and associative ($(A + B) + C = A + (B + C)$) — the same properties as regular number addition. These properties make sense because you're just doing regular number addition at each position. The zero matrix $O$ (all entries 0) is the additive identity: $A + O = A$. These properties will be important when we use matrices to represent systems of equations in Sections 14.4 and 14.6.

classifications.value: Add entry by entry, in the same position; only possible when dimensions match exactly
characteristics: Requirement: both matrices must have identical dimensions ($m \times n$ + $m \times n$ → $m \times n$)
Method: add the entry at position $(i, j)$ in matrix $A$ to the entry at position $(i, j)$ in matrix $B$
Result: a new matrix with the same dimensions as the originals
Cannot add matrices of different dimensions — this is undefined, like adding apples to oranges
Matrix addition is commutative: $A + B = B + A$
Matrix addition is associative: $(A + B) + C = A + (B + C)$
Adding the zero matrix $O$ leaves a matrix unchanged: $A + O = A$
classifications.behavior: Step 1: Check dimensions — both matrices must be the same size. If they aren't, stop and write 'undefined.' Step 2: Create an empty result matrix of the same size. Step 3: Fill in each entry of the result by adding the two corresponding entries. Work systematically: go row by row, left to right within each row. Step 4: Write the completed result matrix. Double-check by counting entries — the result should have the same number of entries as each input.

examples.explanation: $\begin{bmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ 5 & 2 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 7 \\ -3 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$. Check dimensions: both are $2 \times 2$ ✓. Add entry by entry: Position $(1,1)$: $3 + 4 = 7$. Position $(1,2)$: $-1 + 7 = 6$. Position $(2,1)$: $5 + (-3) = 2$. Position $(2,2)$: $2 + 0 = 2$. Result: $\begin{bmatrix} 7 & 6 \\ 2 & 2 \end{bmatrix}$.

$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -2 \\ 4 & -5 & 3 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 6 & 2 & 7 \\ -1 & 3 & -3 \end{bmatrix}$. Both are $2 \times 3$ ✓. Row 1: $1+6=7$, $0+2=2$, $-2+7=5$. Row 2: $4+(-1)=3$, $-5+3=-2$, $3+(-3)=0$. Result: $\begin{bmatrix} 7 & 2 & 5 \\ 3 & -2 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$.

$\begin{bmatrix} x & 4 \\ -2 & y \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ 5 & 7 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} x+3 & 3 \\ 3 & y+7 \end{bmatrix}$. The entries with variables just carry forward — add the constants alongside them. Position $(1,2)$: $4 + (-1) = 3$. Position $(2,1)$: $-2 + 5 = 3$.

Can we add $\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$ ($2 \times 2$) and $\begin{bmatrix} 5 & 0 & -1 \\ 2 & 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$ ($2 \times 3$)? No — the first has 2 columns and the second has 3. There is no matching entry for column 3 of the second matrix. This addition is undefined. Always check dimensions first.

sections.introduction: Matrix subtraction follows the exact same logic as matrix addition — entry by entry — with one twist: you subtract corresponding entries instead of adding them. Same dimension requirement, same structure, just a minus sign.

key_concept.definition: To subtract matrix $B$ from matrix $A$ (both of the same dimension), subtract corresponding entries: the entry at position $(i, j)$ of $A - B$ is $a_{ij} - b_{ij}$. The result is a new matrix with the same dimensions.
key_concept.context: Matrix subtraction is NOT commutative: $A - B \neq B - A$ in general. This is exactly like regular subtraction: $5 - 3 \neq 3 - 5$. The order matters — keep track of which matrix is being subtracted from which. An alternative way to think about it: $A - B = A + (-B)$, where $-B$ is the matrix whose entries are all negated. This additive-inverse framing can help: flip the sign of every entry in $B$, then add.

classifications.type: Matrix Subtraction — Entry by Entry with Order Awareness
classifications.value: Same rule as addition but with subtraction; ORDER MATTERS — $A - B \neq B - A$
characteristics: Requirement: both matrices must have identical dimensions
Method: subtract the $(i,j)$ entry of $B$ from the $(i,j)$ entry of $A$
Result: a new matrix with the same dimensions
NOT commutative: $A - B \neq B - A$ (the signs of all off-diagonal or non-equal entries flip)
Alternative approach: negate all entries in $B$ to get $-B$, then add: $A - B = A + (-B)$
Subtracting the zero matrix $O$ leaves $A$ unchanged: $A - O = A$
classifications.behavior: Step 1: Check dimensions. Step 2: For each position $(i, j)$, compute $a_{ij} - b_{ij}$ — take the entry from $A$ and subtract the entry from $B$ in the same position. Step 3: Write the result. The most common subtraction error is computing $b_{ij} - a_{ij}$ (backward). A useful check: the sign of the result entry should reflect which entry was larger. If $a_{11} = 2$ and $b_{11} = 5$, then $a_{11} - b_{11} = 2 - 5 = -3$ — the result is negative because $B$ had the larger entry.

examples.explanation: $\begin{bmatrix} 8 & 3 \\ -1 & 6 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 7 \\ -4 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$. Both are $2 \times 2$ ✓. Position $(1,1)$: $8-2=6$. Position $(1,2)$: $3-7=-4$. Position $(2,1)$: $-1-(-4)=-1+4=3$. Position $(2,2)$: $6-1=5$. Result: $\begin{bmatrix} 6 & -4 \\ 3 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$.

examples.process: Subtracting with Negative Entries — Watch Double Negatives
examples.explanation: $\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 \\ 0 & -8 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} -3 & 4 \\ -1 & -5 \end{bmatrix}$. Position $(1,1)$: $5-(-3) = 5+3 = 8$. Position $(1,2)$: $-2-4 = -6$. Position $(2,1)$: $0-(-1) = 0+1 = 1$. Position $(2,2)$: $-8-(-5) = -8+5 = -3$. Result: $\begin{bmatrix} 8 & -6 \\ 1 & -3 \end{bmatrix}$. Subtracting a negative entry is a double negative — always rewrite as addition.

examples.process: Why Order Matters — $A - B$ vs. $B - A$
examples.explanation: Let $A = \begin{bmatrix} 6 & 1 \\ -2 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 5 \\ 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$. $A - B = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ -2 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$. $B - A = \begin{bmatrix} -3 & 4 \\ 2 & -5 \end{bmatrix}$. Every entry has the opposite sign. $A - B$ and $B - A$ always produce matrices that are negatives of each other: $B - A = -(A - B)$.

sections.introduction: A scalar is just a regular number (not a matrix). Scalar multiplication means multiplying an entire matrix by a single number. The rule could not be simpler: multiply every single entry in the matrix by that number. No position matching required — just scale everything uniformly.

key_concept.definition: To multiply a matrix $A$ by a scalar $k$, multiply every entry of $A$ by $k$. The result, written $kA$, has the same dimensions as $A$, and every entry $a_{ij}$ becomes $k \cdot a_{ij}$.
key_concept.context: Scalar multiplication is the matrix version of multiplication by a constant. It works on any matrix regardless of its dimensions — there are no dimension requirements to check. It distributes over matrix addition: $k(A + B) = kA + kB$. It also distributes over matrices from a scalar sum: $(k + m)A = kA + mA$. You can factor a scalar out of a matrix the same way you factor a number out of an expression — this technique appears in many later problems.

classifications.value: The simplest matrix operation — no dimension check needed, just multiply every entry by the scalar
characteristics: Multiply EVERY entry in the matrix by the scalar $k$
The result has the same dimensions as the original matrix
Works on any matrix regardless of size
Distributes over addition: $k(A + B) = kA + kB$
Compatible scalars: $(k \cdot m)A = k(mA)$
Scalar $1$ is the multiplicative identity: $1 \cdot A = A$
Scalar $0$ produces the zero matrix: $0 \cdot A = O$
Scalar $-1$ negates every entry: $-1 \cdot A = -A$ (the additive inverse)
classifications.behavior: Multiply the scalar by the first entry, write it down, move to the next entry, multiply by the scalar again, write it down — continue until every entry is done. Work systematically row by row. With a negative scalar, every positive entry becomes negative and every negative entry becomes positive — be careful with double negatives. A common mistake: only multiplying the first row or the diagonal. The scalar touches EVERY entry, no exceptions.

examples.explanation: $3 \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -1 \\ 0 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$. Multiply each entry by 3: $(1,1)$: $3 \times 2 = 6$. $(1,2)$: $3 \times (-1) = -3$. $(2,1)$: $3 \times 0 = 0$. $(2,2)$: $3 \times 5 = 15$. Result: $\begin{bmatrix} 6 & -3 \\ 0 & 15 \end{bmatrix}$.

$-2 \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -3 \\ -1 & 7 \end{bmatrix}$. Multiply each entry by $-2$: $(1,1)$: $-2 \times 4 = -8$. $(1,2)$: $-2 \times (-3) = +6$. $(2,1)$: $-2 \times (-1) = +2$. $(2,2)$: $-2 \times 7 = -14$. Result: $\begin{bmatrix} -8 & 6 \\ 2 & -14 \end{bmatrix}$. Multiplying by a negative flips the sign of every entry.

$\dfrac{1}{2} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 8 & -4 \\ 6 & 10 \end{bmatrix}$. Multiply each entry by $\frac{1}{2}$ (divide by 2): $(1,1)$: $8/2 = 4$. $(1,2)$: $-4/2 = -2$. $(2,1)$: $6/2 = 3$. $(2,2)$: $10/2 = 5$. Result: $\begin{bmatrix} 4 & -2 \\ 3 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$. Fractional scalars divide every entry.

$4 \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -2 & 3 \\ 0 & 5 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$. Every entry — all 6 of them — gets multiplied by 4: Row 1: $4, -8, 12$. Row 2: $0, 20, -4$. Result: $\begin{bmatrix} 4 & -8 & 12 \\ 0 & 20 & -4 \end{bmatrix}$. Scalar multiplication applies to every entry in every row and every column.

sections.section_title: Combining Operations — Expressions with Multiple Matrix Operations
sections.introduction: Real problems rarely ask you to perform just one operation in isolation. More often, you'll need to add and scale matrices together in the same expression — the same way algebraic expressions combine multiple operations. This section shows you how to evaluate those combined expressions step by step, using the same order of operations you already know from regular algebra.

key_concept.definition: Matrix expressions follow the same order of operations as regular algebra: perform scalar multiplications first, then additions and subtractions. When combining matrix operations, always compute each matrix separately first, then combine. The expression $2A + 3B$ means: compute $2A$ (scale $A$ by 2), compute $3B$ (scale $B$ by 3), then add the results.
key_concept.context: Two important properties allow flexibility in combining operations. The distributive property: $k(A + B) = kA + kB$. Factoring: if every entry in a matrix shares a common factor, you can write that factor as a scalar out front. These are the same algebraic moves you've made for years — they work identically with matrices because the operations are all entry-wise.

categories.description: Scalar multiplication first, then addition or subtraction. Compute each scaled matrix separately, then combine entry by entry.
categories.detailed_mechanism: Step 1: Identify all scalar multiplications in the expression. Step 2: Compute each scalar-matrix product. Step 3: Check that all resulting matrices have the same dimensions (required for addition/subtraction). Step 4: Add or subtract the resulting matrices entry by entry. Step 5: Write the final result. This is the standard workflow for any mixed-operation matrix expression.

examples.explanation: Let $A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ -2 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -3 \\ 5 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$. Step 1 — Compute $2A$: $\begin{bmatrix} 6 & 2 \\ -4 & 8 \end{bmatrix}$. Step 2 — Subtract $B$ entry by entry: $(1,1)$: $6-1=5$. $(1,2)$: $2-(-3)=5$. $(2,1)$: $-4-5=-9$. $(2,2)$: $8-0=8$. Result: $\begin{bmatrix} 5 & 5 \\ -9 & 8 \end{bmatrix}$.

Let $A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -1 \\ 0 & 3 \end{bmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{bmatrix} -1 & 4 \\ 2 & -2 \end{bmatrix}$. Step 1 — $3A = \begin{bmatrix} 6 & -3 \\ 0 & 9 \end{bmatrix}$. Step 2 — $2B = \begin{bmatrix} -2 & 8 \\ 4 & -4 \end{bmatrix}$. Step 3 — Add: $(1,1)$: $6+(-2)=4$. $(1,2)$: $-3+8=5$. $(2,1)$: $0+4=4$. $(2,2)$: $9+(-4)=5$. Result: $\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 5 \\ 4 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$.

categories.description: Matrix equations can be solved for an unknown matrix using the same algebraic moves as regular equations — isolate the unknown by adding, subtracting, or scalar-multiplying both sides.
categories.detailed_mechanism: If $A + X = B$, then $X = B - A$. If $2X = A$, then $X = \frac{1}{2}A$. If $3X - B = C$, then $3X = C + B$, so $X = \frac{1}{3}(C + B)$. Every algebraic move from regular equations works here — the only difference is that the operations are applied entry by entry. The key insight: whatever you do to one side of a matrix equation, you do to the other side, using the same operations.

examples.explanation: Given $A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -1 \\ 3 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{bmatrix} 7 & 4 \\ 0 & -2 \end{bmatrix}$, find $X$. Isolate $X$: $X = B - A = \begin{bmatrix} 7-2 & 4-(-1) \\ 0-3 & -2-5 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 & 5 \\ -3 & -7 \end{bmatrix}$.
Given $A = \begin{bmatrix} 10 & -6 \\ 4 & 8 \end{bmatrix}$, find $X$. Divide both sides by 2 (multiply by $\frac{1}{2}$): $X = \frac{1}{2}A = \begin{bmatrix} 5 & -3 \\ 2 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$.

Given $B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ -3 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$ and $C = \begin{bmatrix} 8 & -4 \\ 6 & 9 \end{bmatrix}$, find $X$. Add $B$ to both sides: $3X = C + B = \begin{bmatrix} 9 & -2 \\ 3 & 9 \end{bmatrix}$. Divide by 3: $X = \frac{1}{3}\begin{bmatrix} 9 & -2 \\ 3 & 9 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & -\frac{2}{3} \\ 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}$.

sections.section_title: Real-World Context — Why Matrix Operations Matter
sections.introduction: Matrix operations aren't just abstract arithmetic — they model real situations where data is organized in grids. Adding, subtracting, and scaling matrices becomes a natural way to update inventories, compare datasets, calculate totals, and track changes. Understanding why these operations are useful makes the mechanics feel meaningful rather than mechanical.

key_concept.definition: Matrices are used to organize data with two categories simultaneously — for example, multiple products across multiple stores, or multiple test scores across multiple students. Matrix addition combines datasets, subtraction shows changes, and scalar multiplication scales an entire dataset uniformly.
key_concept.context: Whenever data has two dimensions — rows representing one category (stores, students, days) and columns representing another (products, subjects, activities) — a matrix is the natural container. Operations on these matrices have direct, interpretable real-world meaning. This application focus previews Section 14.10 (Matrix Operations in Real-World Contexts), where these ideas are developed fully.

categories.description: Matrices naturally represent inventory data — rows might be stores and columns might be products. Adding matrices combines inventories; subtracting tracks sales or losses.
categories.detailed_mechanism: If matrix $A$ represents a store's inventory at the start of the week and matrix $B$ represents the items sold during the week, then $A - B$ gives the remaining inventory at week's end. If matrix $C$ represents a shipment received, then $A - B + C$ gives the new inventory. Scalar multiplication scales all quantities — for example, if prices double, multiply the price matrix by 2.

examples.explanation: Store inventory (rows = items: shirts, pants; columns = sizes: S, M, L). Start of week: $A = \begin{bmatrix} 20 & 35 & 15 \\ 10 & 25 & 30 \end{bmatrix}$. Sold this week: $B = \begin{bmatrix} 8 & 12 & 5 \\ 3 & 10 & 14 \end{bmatrix}$. Remaining inventory: $A - B = \begin{bmatrix} 12 & 23 & 10 \\ 7 & 15 & 16 \end{bmatrix}$. Each entry gives the exact remaining count for that item-size combination.

Store 1 inventory: $A = \begin{bmatrix} 15 & 20 \\ 8 & 12 \end{bmatrix}$. Store 2 inventory: $B = \begin{bmatrix} 10 & 18 \\ 5 & 9 \end{bmatrix}$. Combined total for the company: $A + B = \begin{bmatrix} 25 & 38 \\ 13 & 21 \end{bmatrix}$. Adding the two store matrices gives the company-wide total at each position (item-size combination).

A restaurant's prices (rows = items; columns = sizes) are stored in matrix $P = \begin{bmatrix} 8 & 10 & 12 \\ 5 & 7 & 9 \end{bmatrix}$ (in dollars). If the restaurant raises all prices by 15%, multiply by $1.15$: $1.15P = \begin{bmatrix} 9.20 & 11.50 & 13.80 \\ 5.75 & 8.05 & 10.35 \end{bmatrix}$. Every price in the matrix increases proportionally.

categories.description: Student scores across multiple subjects and multiple assignments are naturally organized in matrices. Adding, subtracting, and scaling produce meaningful academic summaries.
categories.detailed_mechanism: If rows represent students and columns represent assignments, adding matrices combines scores from two grading periods; subtracting shows improvement or decline; scalar multiplication converts raw scores to weighted scores or adjusts for a curve.

examples.explanation: Midterm scores (rows = students A, B, C; columns = Math, English, Science): $M = \begin{bmatrix} 88 & 75 & 92 \\ 70 & 85 & 78 \\ 95 & 68 & 81 \end{bmatrix}$. Final scores: $F = \begin{bmatrix} 91 & 80 & 88 \\ 74 & 79 & 85 \\ 90 & 72 & 94 \end{bmatrix}$. Improvement from midterm to final: $F - M = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 5 & -4 \\ 4 & -6 & 7 \\ -5 & 4 & 13 \end{bmatrix}$. Positive entries = improvement; negative entries = decline.

A teacher wants to add 5 points to every score in matrix $M$ above. Rather than adding 5 to each entry individually, add a matrix of all 5s: $M + \begin{bmatrix} 5 & 5 & 5 \\ 5 & 5 & 5 \\ 5 & 5 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$. Or: scale an all-ones matrix. The matrix framework makes bulk adjustments efficient.

sections.introduction: These worked examples require multiple operations in sequence, solving for unknowns, and connecting calculations to context. They model the depth expected on assessments.

key_concept.definition: Multi-step matrix problems require: (1) identifying dimensions and checking compatibility, (2) performing operations in the correct order, (3) keeping careful track of signs especially with negative entries, and (4) interpreting the result in context when a real-world situation is given.
key_concept.context: The most important habit for multi-step problems: write out each intermediate matrix fully before moving to the next step. Trying to do multiple operations simultaneously leads to entry errors that cascade through the rest of the problem.

worked_examples.title: Evaluating a Matrix Expression with Three Matrices

step_by_step.explanation: All three matrices must have the same dimension for this expression to be defined.
step_by_step.calculation: $A$: $2 \times 2$. $B$: $2 \times 2$. $C$: $2 \times 2$. All match ✓. The result will also be $2 \times 2$.

step_by_step.explanation: Add $C$ to the result from Step 4, entry by entry.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Always compute scalar multiplications before additions and subtractions. Write out each intermediate matrix fully before combining — do not try to merge steps.

worked_examples.title: Solving a Matrix Equation for an Unknown Matrix
worked_examples.problem: Find matrix $X$ such that $3X - A = B$, where $A = \begin{bmatrix} 6 & -3 \\ 0 & 9 \end{bmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{bmatrix} 15 & 3 \\ -6 & 12 \end{bmatrix}$.

step_by_step.explanation: Treat this like an algebraic equation. Isolate $X$ using inverse operations.
step_by_step.calculation: $3X - A = B$. Goal: get $X$ alone on one side.

step_by_step.explanation: Add $A$ to both sides of the equation to eliminate $-A$ on the left.
Multiply both sides by $\frac{1}{3}$ to isolate $X$.
Substitute back into the original equation to confirm.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Solving a matrix equation uses the same algebraic moves as solving a regular equation — add, subtract, or multiply both sides — but every operation is performed entry by entry. Verification by substitution is always worth the time.

worked_examples.title: Real-World: Two-Store Inventory Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A clothing company has two stores. Their current inventory (rows = product: jackets, jeans; columns = color: black, blue, gray) is: Store 1: $A = \begin{bmatrix} 30 & 45 & 20 \\ 50 & 60 & 35 \end{bmatrix}$, Store 2: $B = \begin{bmatrix} 25 & 30 & 40 \\ 45 & 55 & 20 \end{bmatrix}$. (a) Find the total combined inventory across both stores. (b) This week, a shipment doubles Store 1's current inventory. Find Store 1's new inventory. (c) Store 1 sells: $S = \begin{bmatrix} 10 & 15 & 8 \\ 18 & 22 & 12 \end{bmatrix}$ units. Find Store 1's inventory after the shipment and sales.

step_by_step.explanation: Add the two store matrices to find total inventory at each position.
step_by_step.calculation: $A + B = \begin{bmatrix} 30+25 & 45+30 & 20+40 \\ 50+45 & 60+55 & 35+20 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 55 & 75 & 60 \\ 95 & 115 & 55 \end{bmatrix}$. Interpretation: the company has 55 black jackets, 75 blue jackets, 60 gray jackets, 95 black jeans, 115 blue jeans, and 55 gray jeans total.

step_by_step.explanation: Doubling the current inventory means multiplying by 2.
step_by_step.calculation: $2A = \begin{bmatrix} 2(30) & 2(45) & 2(20) \\ 2(50) & 2(60) & 2(35) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 60 & 90 & 40 \\ 100 & 120 & 70 \end{bmatrix}$. Store 1 now has 60 black jackets, 90 blue jackets, etc.

step_by_step.step: Part (c): Store 1 After Shipment Then Sales
step_by_step.explanation: Start with the doubled inventory $2A$, then subtract sales matrix $S$.
step_by_step.calculation: $2A - S = \begin{bmatrix} 60-10 & 90-15 & 40-8 \\ 100-18 & 120-22 & 70-12 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 50 & 75 & 32 \\ 82 & 98 & 58 \end{bmatrix}$. Interpretation: after receiving the shipment and selling $S$ units, Store 1 has 50 black jackets, 75 blue jackets, 32 gray jackets, 82 black jeans, 98 blue jeans, and 58 gray jeans remaining.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Combined: $\begin{bmatrix} 55 & 75 & 60 \\ 95 & 115 & 55 \end{bmatrix}$. (b) After shipment: $\begin{bmatrix} 60 & 90 & 40 \\ 100 & 120 & 70 \end{bmatrix}$. (c) After shipment and sales: $\begin{bmatrix} 50 & 75 & 32 \\ 82 & 98 & 58 \end{bmatrix}$.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Real-world matrix problems require connecting each operation to its meaning. Addition combines data; subtraction removes items; scalar multiplication scales uniformly. Identifying what the rows and columns represent before computing makes interpretation straightforward.

sections.section_title: Common Mistakes and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Matrix operations have a small number of specific, repeatable error patterns. These are the mistakes that appear on every assessment — knowing them in advance means you can catch them before they cost you points.

key_concept.definition: The four most common errors in matrix operations: (1) attempting operations on matrices with incompatible dimensions, (2) adding or subtracting matrices as if one number applies to the whole matrix rather than entry by entry, (3) sign errors with negative entries and double negatives in subtraction, and (4) only partially applying scalar multiplication (forgetting some entries).
key_concept.context: Every error in this list is preventable with one habit: slow down and work systematically, entry by entry, checking dimensions before you start. The operations themselves are not difficult — the errors come from rushing.

categories.type: Mistake 1: Attempting to Add or Subtract Matrices of Different Dimensions
categories.description: Matrix addition and subtraction require identical dimensions. Many students try to add matrices that differ in size, guessing at how to align them.
categories.detailed_mechanism: There is no way to add a $2 \times 3$ matrix to a $3 \times 2$ matrix — even though both have 6 entries, they don't have matching positions. The operation is simply undefined. The fix: always state the dimensions of both matrices before computing. If they don't match, write 'undefined' and stop.

examples.explanation: Given $A$ ($3 \times 2$) and $B$ ($3 \times 3$). Can we compute $A + B$? Check: $A$ is $3 \times 2$, $B$ is $3 \times 3$. Different number of columns (2 vs. 3). Addition is undefined. There is no valid answer — not even with zeros in the extra column.

categories.description: Students often multiply only the first row, only the diagonal entries, or only a few entries by the scalar — missing one or more.
categories.detailed_mechanism: The scalar multiplies EVERY entry — no exceptions. In a $3 \times 3$ matrix, that's 9 multiplications. In a $2 \times 4$ matrix, that's 8 multiplications. Work row by row, left to right, and count entries when finished — if the count doesn't match the matrix dimensions, you missed one.

examples.explanation: $3 \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 4 \\ 1 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$. WRONG: $\begin{bmatrix} 6 & 4 \\ 1 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$ (only multiplied the $(1,1)$ entry). WRONG: $\begin{bmatrix} 6 & 12 \\ 1 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$ (only multiplied the first row). CORRECT: $\begin{bmatrix} 6 & 12 \\ 3 & 15 \end{bmatrix}$ (every entry multiplied by 3).

categories.type: Mistake 3: Sign Errors in Subtraction — Double Negatives
categories.description: When subtracting a matrix that contains negative entries, double negatives are extremely common. Subtracting a negative entry produces a sum, not a difference.
categories.detailed_mechanism: When computing $a_{ij} - b_{ij}$ and $b_{ij}$ is negative, the computation becomes $a_{ij} - (\text{negative number}) = a_{ij} + (\text{positive number})$. Students often forget the second negative and subtract the magnitude instead. Fix: when $b_{ij}$ is negative, always rewrite the subtraction as addition before calculating. Write $a_{ij} - (-k) = a_{ij} + k$ explicitly.

examples.explanation: $\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} -5 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$. Entry $(1,1)$: $3 - (-5)$. Do NOT compute $3-5=-2$. Rewrite: $3-(-5) = 3+5 = 8$. Entry $(1,2)$: $1-4 = -3$. Result: $\begin{bmatrix} 8 & -3 \end{bmatrix}$.

categories.type: Mistake 4: Confusing Row and Column Order in Dimensions
categories.description: Students reverse the dimension notation — writing $n \times m$ when the matrix is $m \times n$.
categories.detailed_mechanism: Dimensions are ALWAYS rows first, columns second — $m \times n$. A matrix with 3 rows and 4 columns is $3 \times 4$, never $4 \times 3$. This matters because a $3 \times 4$ and a $4 \times 3$ matrix cannot be added together, but students who mix up the notation might think they can. Memory aid: 'RC Cola' — Rows Come first, then Columns.

examples.explanation: Matrix $A$ has 4 rows and 2 columns. Dimension: $4 \times 2$ (RC — rows first). Matrix $B$ has 2 rows and 4 columns. Dimension: $2 \times 4$ (still RC — rows first). Can $A + B$ be computed? $A$ is $4 \times 2$; $B$ is $2 \times 4$. Different dimensions — undefined. Without the RC rule, students might say 'both have 4 and 2, so they match' — wrong.

categories.type: Mistake 5: Reversing Subtraction — Computing $b_{ij} - a_{ij}$ Instead of $a_{ij} - b_{ij}$
categories.description: In $A - B$, you subtract $B$'s entries FROM $A$'s entries — not the other way around. Reversing the order gives the negated result.
categories.detailed_mechanism: $A - B$ means: for every position, take the entry in $A$ and subtract the corresponding entry in $B$. Students who lose track of which matrix is first sometimes compute $B - A$ instead, which negates every entry. Fix: before computing each entry in $A - B$, write the entry from $A$ first, then subtract the entry from $B$.

examples.explanation: $A = \begin{bmatrix} 5 & 2 \end{bmatrix}$, $B = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 8 \end{bmatrix}$. $A - B$: $(5-3, 2-8) = (2, -6)$. $B - A$: $(3-5, 8-2) = (-2, 6)$. Every sign is flipped. These are completely different results. Read the problem carefully — is it $A - B$ or $B - A$?

summary: A matrix is an $m \times n$ rectangular array of numbers (rows first, columns second — the RC rule). Each entry is denoted $a_{ij}$ (row $i$, column $j$). Matrix addition and subtraction are only defined when both matrices have identical dimensions — then you operate entry by entry: $(A \pm B)_{ij} = a_{ij} \pm b_{ij}$. Addition is commutative ($A + B = B + A$) and associative; subtraction is not commutative ($A - B \neq B - A$). Scalar multiplication multiplies every entry of a matrix by the scalar $k$: $(kA)_{ij} = k \cdot a_{ij}$; no dimension check is required. For combined expressions like $2A - 3B + C$, compute all scalar products first, then add and subtract the resulting matrices. Matrix equations are solved like regular algebraic equations — add, subtract, or scale both sides — performing each operation entry by entry. These operations have direct real-world meaning: addition combines datasets, subtraction shows change, and scalar multiplication scales uniformly. The zero matrix $O$ is the additive identity ($A + O = A$), and $-A$ is the additive inverse ($A + (-A) = O$). These foundations lead directly to matrix multiplication in Section 14.2, where dimension rules become more complex.
